title: As a writer...
body: The fact that I find myself having to look up words and their meanings to understand some of the descriptive language in _Shadow and Fortune_ is making me giddy.  I love learning new descriptive words, and these things are packed full of it.  Loving it.

> [{quoted}](name=Sciela,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=cqxQl8QT,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-10-29T22:56:06.740+0000)

lambent - Which is basically a synonym for "radiant" or "glowing" or "luminous" which is useful if you need more than those words to refer to something.

And

pellucid - Which is a synonym for "transparent" or "clear" or "unclouded" which was used to describe the energy coming off Hecarim, I believe.

As far as your "do not use" list, I'd toss that right out the window.  Language is a means of expression, and the narrative voice is only as varied as the tones you can take with it, and those tones are tied to the words you use.  If all you do is write so a middle-school student can understand your writing, then you're closing yourself off from things that sound more surreal, more captivating and otherworldly.  Without such things, we'd be absent such great lines as "The weft and weave of fate guides..." and the like.  And Tahm Kench wouldn't have his unique "flavor".  Descriptive text is not just about what you're writing about, but how it is written, and the images the language evokes from its readers.

I actually had to look up pellucid myself. :P 

Lambent has a different connotation than the other words though (whether that's just the word itself or how it's frequently used, I don't know) in that it's more of a sickly, creepy glow (though it can also refer to just firelight, depends on how you use it) -- it's not a word I see often, so it's nice to see someone at Riot use it.

It's not that I can -never- use those words, it's just that, as a whole, my piece needs to be written so that a child can read it, because the average American adult's vocabulary is around an 8th grader's (my English professor told me this). So, if I want my book or story or whatever to be readable as a whole, it can't be written with all kinds of fancy / infrequently used words -- though that doesn't mean I'm entirely barred from using them.

No offense intended.  I just find myself using the same word or phrases over and over in my writings due to my lack of vocabulary (I'm a college student, it's rather embarrassing since I want to be a professional writer one day.  Sadly I ignored my grammar lessons).  So learning more is always helpful.

Personally, I had to look up certain archaic expressions such as "awl" or "lapels" (taken from chapter 1). The story has more of these, but these are some that just crossed my mind. Anyway it's nice to see a native speaker admit lacking vocabulary, :P even better when he/she's willing to learn.

I don't mind the fact that I lack vocabulary skills.  Really I think people put too much blame on schools for not teaching stuff well.  It can be taught if the kids actually gave a damn, problem is that people really don't most of the time.

But that's a different topic.  Thank you for not insulting me as many expect when they reveal their lack of knowledge is something considered basic.  :D

The characters are simplistic in this compared to Burning Tides, but it's also a different sort of story.  Honestly the biggest thing that irks me is the frequent use of the word "said" after so many parts of dialogue.  The way that I write in my personal style is to eliminate that word as completely as possible.  Rather, I tie the language to what the character is doing at the moment they're replying or talking with their scene partner.  Or, if I have to say who said something that directly, I try to use a synonym, rather than reusing "said" again and again.

Maybe it's just me.

The way you are introducing? (is that the correct word? I'm not an expert on English literary theory) direct speech is definitely more interesting than just abusing the verb "said". However, I'm sure you'd grow weary of it after few hundred pages. The people writing the story are mercenaries of literature: paid for creating easy-to-consume tales for people to read. You definitely need talent for that, but you can't really say any of them would be the work of their life. :P
Details like that are usually only apparent to somebody who is experienced with writing, so no wonder you might feel like the sole discoverer. I'm neither writer, nor native English speaker, so the details pass over me as well. ;)

It's not so much that I get weary of it, because it adds more depth to the characters in my personal experience.  Half or more of what we say is in how we say something, and what we do while we're speaking.  For example, if you say something like...
 
> Angry curses followed him down.
> 
> He spun out into a trailing forest of ropes and pulleys, flags and pennants. He thrashed as he fell, tangling his limbs and weapon. Fate was mocking him, wrapping him in a folded shroud of canvas sailcloth.
> 
> “Not like this, damn it!” he roared. “Not like this!”

The pause where the author stops to say that he roared splits the story and slows it down.

But, if you rewrite the same thing just slightly...
 
>"Not like this, damn it!  Not like this!" 
>
> He spun out into a trailing forest of ropes and pulleys, flags and pennants. He thrashed and roared as he fell, tangling his limbs and weapon. Fate was mocking him, wrapping him in a folded shroud of canvas sailcloth.
>
>And his angry curses followed him down.

It's very clear who is speaking, and the story continues onward fairly fluidly.  There's no pause to mention how he's speaking, instead it is incorporated into the narration itself, and it gives an idea that the story is continuing onward at the same time.

Again, everyone is a critic, and this is just my personal taste.  But there's nothing actually "wrong" with how it was written.  It's style.  I just happen to prefer it my way as opposed to using "said" and the like.

That was a very thorough comment and a good example. But the message is clear: each of us does things differently, and there's nothing wrong about that. I could go on with the topic, but this isn't the right place, and the point is taken. ;)
